review.title: Computational Sociolinguistics: A Survey
review.abstract: Language is a social phenomenon and inherent to its social nature is that it is constantly changing. Recently, a surge of interest can be observed within the computational linguistics (CL) community in the social dimension of language. In this article we present a survey of the emerging field of "Computational Sociolinguistics" that reflects this increased interest. We aim to provide a comprehensive overview of CL research on sociolinguistic themes, featuring topics such as the relation between language and social identity, language use in social interaction and multilingual communication. Moreover, we demonstrate the potential for synergy between the research communities involved, by showing how the large-scale data-driven methods that are widely used in CL can complement existing sociolinguistic studies, and how sociolinguistics can inform and challenge the methods and assumptions employed in CL studies. We hope to convey the possible benefits of a closer collaboration between the two communities and conclude with a discussion of open challenges.

sections.heading: 2. Methods for Computational Sociolinguistics
sections.text: As discussed, an important objective of this article is to promote cooperation between the fields of sociolinguistics in particular and social sciences research related to communication in the broader sense on the one hand and computational linguistics on the other. By focusing on the relationship with methods from sociolinguistics and the social sciences in general, we are able to underline two expectations. First, we are convinced that sociolinguistics and related fields can help the field of computational linguistics to develop richer models that are more effective for the tasks for which they can be used. Second, the time seems right for the CL community to contribute to sociolinguistics and social sciences, not only by developing and adapting tools for sociolinguists, but also by refining theoretical models within sociolinguistics through computational approaches and contributions to understanding the social dynamics of natural language.

sections.heading: 4. Language and Social Interaction
sections.text: In the previous section, we explored computer-aided approaches to examine how language shapes our identity. We discussed variables such as gender, age, and geographical location, focusing on the variation between speakers. Speakers, however, do not act in isolation, but are part of couples, groups, and communities. Therefore, there is a lot of variation within individual speakers, as language also varies according to context, including the recipient or target audience, the topic, and the social goals of speakers. Next, we discuss computer-aided approaches to examine how language reflects and shapes our social relationships (Section 4.2). Much of this work revolves around the role of language in power dynamics by exploring how speakers use language to maintain and change power relationships.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: While the field of computational linguistics has historically focused on the interpretation and manipulation of the sentence content of language, a different valid view of language is that it is a dynamic, social entity. While some aspects of language are predictable from a social perspective and therefore behave similarly to other aspects that are more frequently the subject of research in this area, we must acknowledge that linguistic action has played a large part in how language is used to construct social identities, build and maintain social relationships, and even define the boundaries of communities. With the increasing research into social media data and in parallel with the advent of computational social science, we have observed a sharp increase in interest within the computational linguistic community in sociolinguistic topics. In this article, we have defined and set out a research agenda for the emerging field of "computational sociolinguistics." We have set ourselves the goal of providing a comprehensive overview of studies published in the field of CL that touch on sociolinguistic topics, in order to provide a sociolinguistic overview of what has been achieved so far for sociolinguistic space and where there is a socio-space.

metadata.abstractText: Language is a social phenomenon and inherent to its social nature is that it is constantly changing. Recently, a surge of interest can be observed within the computational linguistics (CL) community in the social dimension of language. In this article we present a survey of the emerging field of ‘Computational Sociolinguistics’ that reflects this increased interest. We aim to provide a comprehensive overview of CL research on sociolinguistic themes, featuring topics such as the relation between language and social identity, language use in social interaction and multilingual communication. Moreover, we demonstrate the potential for synergy between the research communities involved, by showing how the large-scale data-driven methods that are widely used in CL can complement existing sociolinguistic studies, and how sociolinguistics can inform and challenge the methods and assumptions employed in CL studies. We hope to convey the possible benefits of a closer collaboration between the two communities and conclude with a discussion of open challenges.
